text: Paul’s Approach to Ministry in Thessalonica
For \add you\add* yourselves know, brothers, our reception with you, that it was not in vain,
but \add after we\add* had already suffered and been mistreated in Philippi, just as you know, we had the courage in our God to speak to you the gospel of God amid much opposition.
For our exhortation \add is\add* not from error or from impurity or with deceit,
but just as we have been approved by God to be entrusted with the gospel, thus we speak, not as pleasing people but God, who examines our hearts.
⸤For never⸥\f + \fr 2:5 \ft Literally “for neither ever” \f* did we come with a word of flattery, just as you know, nor with a pretext of greediness (God \add is\add* witness),
nor seeking glory from people, neither from you nor from others.

⸤Although we could have insisted on our own importance⸥\f + \fr 2:7 \ft Literally “being able to be with a claim of importance” \f*\ef + \fr 2:7 \ft ﻿*Here the participle (“being able”) is understood as concessive \ef* as apostles of Christ, yet we became infants in your midst, like a nursing mother cherishes her own children.
Longing for you in this way, we determined to share with you not only the gospel of God but also our own souls, because you had become dear to us.
For you remember, brothers, our labor and hardship: working by night and day in order not to be a burden to any of you, we proclaimed to you the gospel of God.
You \add are\add* witnesses, and \add so is\add* God, how devoutly and righteously and blamelessly we became to you who believe,
just as you know how \add we treated\add* each one of you, like a father his own children,
exhorting and consoling you and insisting that you live in a manner worthy of God, who calls you to his own kingdom and glory.
The Thessalonians’ Response to Paul’s Message

And because of this we also give thanks to God constantly, that \add when you\add*\ef + \fr 2:13 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“received”) which is understood as temporal \ef* received God’s word ⸤that you heard⸥\f + \fr 2:13 \ft Literally “of hearing” \f* from us, you accepted \add it\add* not \add as the\add* word of men, but as \add it\add* truly is, \add the\add* word of God, which also is at work in you who believe.

For you became imitators, brothers, of the churches of God \add which\add* are in Judea in Christ Jesus, because you also suffered the same \add things\add* at the hands of your own people, just as \add they\add* themselves \add did\add* also at the hands of the Jews,
who killed both the Lord Jesus and the prophets, and who persecuted us, and \add who are\add* not pleasing to God and \add are\add* opposed to all people,

hindering us from speaking to the Gentiles in order that they may be saved, so that \add they\add* always fill up their sins. But wrath has come upon them to the end.\f + \fr 2:16 \ft Or “has come upon them at last” \f*
Paul’s Desire to Revisit the Thessalonians

But \add when\add*\ef + \fr 2:17 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“were made orphans by separation”) which is understood as temporal \ef* we were made orphans by separation from you, brothers, for ⸤a short time⸥\f + \fr 2:17 \ft Literally “the time of an hour” \f* (in face, not in heart), \add we were\add* even more eager with great desire to see your face,
because we wanted to come to you—I, Paul, ⸤on more than one occasion⸥\f + \fr 2:18 \ft Literally “both once and twice” \f*—and Satan hindered us.
For who \add is\add* our hope or joy or crown of boasting? \add Is it\add* not even you, in the presence of our Lord Jesus at his coming?
For you are our glory and joy.
